facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 532 of 1966 in Civil Appellate Jurisdiction.

facts.text: Appeal filed in forma pauperis by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: .  In forma pauperis . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 17, 1962 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 22 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 17, 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 22 of 1962. V. Goswami, for the

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur dismissed the suit of the appellant for declaration of ownership and possession of suit properties.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal in forma pauperis by special leave from a judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur dismissing the suit of the appellant for a declar

facts.text: Jangi Jogi inherited from his father properties consisting of some groves and a house in village Mukupdpur in erstwhile State of Rewa later part of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Jangi Jogi had inherited from his father properties companysisting of some groves and a house in village Mukupdpur which was in the erstwhile State of Rewa which

facts.text: Jangi Jogi had a son Laldas who died in 1945 leaving the appellant, his widow, as his heir.

anchor.surface_text: He had a son Laldas who is stated to have died in 1945 leaving the appellant, his widow, as, his heir and legal representative.

facts.text: After death of Laldas, Jangi Jogi married Mst. Jugli Bai in 1948.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Laldas Jangi Jogi is alleged to have married Mst. Jugli Bai in the year 1948.

facts.text: Jangi Jogi died sometime in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Jangi Jogi himself died sometime in 1950.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 raised claim to properties of Jangi Jogi by virtue of a gift deed.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 is stated to have raised a claim to the properties of Jangi Jogi by virtue of a gift deed.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 moved criminal courts under S. 145 CrPC and on December 29, 1962 order made directing possession to him.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of that deed be moved the criminal companyrts under S. 145, Criminal Procedure Code and on December 29, 1962 an order was made directing the possess

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit in court of Civil Judge at Rewa for declaration of rights and possession, along with Jugli Bai.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, therefore, instituted a suit in the companyrt of Civil judge at Rewa for a declaration in respect of her rights and for possession of the properti

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 pleaded continuous possession for more than 12 years and ownership by prescription.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 who was the sole defendant in the suit put up several pleas claiming, inter alia. that he had been in companytinuous possession of the suit

facts.text: Respondent pleaded thumb impression of Jugli Bai on plaint obtained by fraud.

facts.text: Trial court framed 12 issues.

anchor.surface_text: On the pleadings of the parties the trial companyrt framed as many as 12 issues.

facts.text: During pendency of suit, plaintiff No. 2 Jugli Bai entered into compromise with respondent No. 1 giving up claims.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the suit plaintiff No. 2 Jugli Bai entered into companypromise with respondent No. 1 giving up all her claims.

facts.text: Trial court found thumb impression of plaintiff not obtained by fraud but she changed sides disadvantaging appellant.

facts.text: Trial court found Jangi Jogi never made gift to respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the deed of gift set up by respondent No. 1, it was found that Jangi Jogi had never made such a gift.

facts.text: Trial court found appellant in possession until dispossessed by respondent No. 1 via S.145 CrPC proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It was further found that the appellant was in possession until she had been dispossessed by respondent No. 1 by means of the proceedings under s. 145, Cr.P.C.

facts.text: Trial court found respondent No. 1 illegally occupied lands and put into possession via S.145.

anchor.surface_text: According to the trial companyrt the said respondent had illegally occupied the lands for some time and since the proceedings under s. 145, Cr.P.C., resulted

facts.text: Trial court found respondent No. 1 position as mere trespasser.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the title of respondent No. 1 was companycerned it was found that his position was that of a mere trespasser.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed appellant's suit because estate devolved on Jugli Bai who compromised.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt, however, numbersuited the appellant on the ground that since her husband had died in the lifetime of Jangi Jogi the latters estate devolved

facts.text: Appellant appealed to District Judge Rewa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant went up in appeal to the companyrt of District Judge, Rewa.

facts.text: District Judge set aside trial court decree, remanded case for fresh disposal as compromise not binding on appellant and trial court did not decide all issues.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed second appeal to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 filed a second appeal before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held appellant could have no interest in properties of Jangi Jogi.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the present appellant companyld have numberinterest in the properties left by Jangi Jogi.

facts.text: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937 extended to Rewa State by Part C States Laws Act 1950 effective April 16, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jugli Bai's application under O.23 r.1 withdraws only her claim; compromise under O.23 r.3 affects only her, not co-plaintiff appellant.

holdings.text: It cannot be disputed that the appellant who is the widow of a predeceased son of Jangi Jogi was entitled to receive maintenance so long as she did not remarry out of the estate of her father-in-law.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that the appellant who is the widow of a predeceased son of Jangi Jogi was entitled to receive maintenance so long as she did number remarry out of the estate of her father-in-law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Hindu law, widow of predeceased son entitled to maintenance from father-in-law's estate unless remarries.

holdings.text: her right was not liable to be defeated except by transfer to a bona fide purchaser for value without notice of a claim or even with notice of the claim unless the transfer was made with the intention of defeating her right.

anchor.surface_text: Although her claim for maintenance was number a charge upon the estate until it had been fixed and specifically charged thereupon her right was number liable to be defeated except by transfer to a bona fide purchaser for value without numberice of a claim or even with numberice of the claim unless the transfer was made with the intention of defeating her right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Maintenance right protected against transfers without securing provision; applies even to heir like Jugli Bai.

holdings.text: she was presumably in possession of these properties in lieu of her right of maintenance and could not be deprived of them even by Jugli Bai without first securing proper maintenance for her out of the aforesaid properties.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is difficult to understand how the appellant could be deprived of the possession of property by a trespasser. Moreover she was presumably in possession of these properties in lieu of her right of maintenance and could number be deprived of them even by Jugli Bai without first securing proper maintenance for her out of the aforesaid properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Possession held in lieu of maintenance protected; cites Indian courts' view and Hindu Succession Act Explanation.

holdings.text: The possession of the plaintiff was sufficient evidence of title as owner against the defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The possession of the plaintiff was sufficient evidence of title as owner against the defendant. By S. 9 of the Specific Relief Act Act 1 of 1877 , if the plaintiff had been dispossessed otherwise than in due course of law, he could,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Privy Council precedent: prior possession proves title against wrong-doer/trespasser; S.9 Specific Relief Act supports recovery.

holdings.text: it must be held that the High Court was in error in considering that since Jugli Bai had entered into some compromise with respondent No. 1 the trial court was justified in dismissing the appellants suit.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping the above statement of law in view it must be held that the High Court was in error in considering that since Jugli Bai had entered into some compromise with respondent No. 1 the trial court was justified in dismissing the appellants suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compromise binds only parties to it; does not clothe trespasser with title or justify dismissing non-party appellant's suit.

holdings.text: If the findings of the trial court was right that respondent No. 1 was a mere trespasser, it is not possible to see how Jugli Bai could effect a transfer of all her rights by merely filing a petition to the effect that she did not wish to prosecute the suit as a co-plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: It is somewhat difficult to understand the observation of the High Court that respondent No. 1 was clothed with the very same rights which were possessed by Jugli Bai. If the findings of the trial court was right that respondent No. 1 was a mere trespasser, it is not possible to see how Jugli Bai could effect a transfer of all her rights by merely filing a petition to the effect that she did number wish to prosecute the suit as a co-plaintiff.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court finding of trespasser status accepted; compromise/withdrawal cannot confer title on trespasser.

holdings.text: The appellant had a possessory title and was entitled to restoration of possession in case it was found that respondent No. 1 had no right, title or interest whatsoever and was a mere trespasser.

anchor.surface_text: As has been pointed out the appellant had a possessory title and was entitled to restoration of possession in case it was found that respondent No. 1 had number right, title or interest whatsoever and was a mere trespasser.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts trial court's findings on possession and trespass; applies possessory title doctrine against wrong-doer.

holdings.text: The rights of the appellant who was in possession qua respondent No. 1 who was found by the trial court to be a trespasser have not been properly considered by the Court.

anchor.surface_text: The rights of the appellant who was in possession qua respondent No. 1 who was found by the trial court to be a trespasser have number been properly considered by the Court. On this point reference may be made to a decision of the Privy Council in Ismail Ariff v. Mohamed Ghouse .

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.145 CrPC gave possession to trespasser but does not confer title; prior possessory rights not extinguished.

holdings.text: the decision of the High Court has to be reversed and that of the District Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we have taken the decision of the High Court has to be reversed and that of the District Judge restored. The appeal is thus allowed with costs here and in the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on legal rights and failed to consider trial findings; District Judge correctly remanded for full trial.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is difficult to understand how the appellant could be deprived of the possession of property by a trespasser. Moreover she was presumably in possession of these properties in lieu of her right of maintenance and could number be deprived of them even by Jugli Bai without first securing proper maintenance for her out of the aforesaid properties.
In the view that we have taken the decision of the High Court has to be reversed and that of the District Judge restored. The appeal is thus allowed with costs here and in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping the above statement of law in view it must be held that the High Court was in error in considering that since Jugli Bai had entered into some compromise with respondent No. 1 the trial court was justified in dismissing the appellants suit.
In the view that we have taken the decision of the High Court has to be reversed and that of the District Judge restored. The appeal is thus allowed with costs here and in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is somewhat difficult to understand the observation of the High Court that respondent No. 1 was clothed with the very same rights which were possessed by Jugli Bai. If the findings of the trial court was right that respondent No. 1 was a mere trespasser, it is not possible to see how Jugli Bai could effect a transfer of all her rights by merely filing a petition to the effect that she did number wish to prosecute the suit as a co-plaintiff.
In the view that we have taken the decision of the High Court has to be reversed and that of the District Judge restored. The appeal is thus allowed with costs here and in the High Court.

edges.explanation: Holding on appellant's possessory title and restoration addresses the prior possession issue

anchor.surface_text: As has been pointed out the appellant had a possessory title and was entitled to restoration of possession in case it was found that respondent No. 1 had number right, title or interest whatsoever and was a mere trespasser.
In the view that we have taken the decision of the High Court has to be reversed and that of the District Judge restored. The appeal is thus allowed with costs here and in the High Court.

The rights of the appellant who was in possession qua respondent No. 1 who was found by the trial court to be a trespasser have number been properly considered by the Court. On this point reference may be made to a decision of the Privy Council in Ismail Ariff v. Mohamed Ghouse .
In the view that we have taken the decision of the High Court has to be reversed and that of the District Judge restored. The appeal is thus allowed with costs here and in the High Court.
